CatDescriptText: F.H. Sheraden, clerk, Corliss and Clyde Schatzman, clerk, East End, was part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in the Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, November 25, 1961, pg. 7 with question: "Do you think Negroes should hold high political offices, particularly those which have payrolls attached?" F.H. Sheraden's answer reads: "I've never had anything against Negroes holding such offices.  And the reason is that I know we all have to make a living.  And, at the same time, I feel Negroes should have the same opportunities in life as whites...."  Clyde Schatzman's answer reads: "Sure.  If a man's qualified, he should be given the job regardless of race, color or creed."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of F.H. Sheraden wearing light colored fedora with dark band, eyeglasses, diagonally striped tie, and light colored flecked overcoat with leather buttons, standing in front of ribbed metal wall, Downtown; Portrait of Clyde Schatzman wearing eyeglasses, plaid shirt with opened collar, and zippered jacket, holding wrapped package and standing in front of ribbed metal wall, Downtown
